intro: Siler caucasicum, commonly known as Caucasian siler, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus. It belongs to theApiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic compounds and often hollow stems. The plant typically grows to a height of 60–120 cm, with finely divided, fern-like leaves and small white or greenish flowers arranged in umbels. Its roots are fibrous and have been used in traditional medicine for their purported tonic and antispasmodic properties. Siler caucasicum thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats.
